body: JOSÉ SANTIAGO, 39, has been around Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, ever since he was a child and started spending summers in the neighborhood with his father, a building superintendent who worked there. Mr. Santiago is a building superintendent himself now, living and working just down the street from where his father lived and worked. It is a good
title: DISPATCHES; Crime Is Low, but Fear Knows No Numbers

body: FOR CHILDREN CHILDREN'S READING SERIES While Charlotte Jones Voiklis and Léna Roy were growing up, they were sometimes allowed into what their grandmother called the Ivory Tower, her work room in her Connecticut house. To keep the girls quiet, she would have them read the projects she was drafting. Though such a strategy would rarely succeed in
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: FOR CHILDREN 'BASH THE TRASH 'N' ASIA' (Sunday) It is what it sounds like. The members of Bash the Trash will engage their audience -- this program is for ages 3 to 6 -- in making instruments from recycled junk. An interactive concert follows, in which two members of Yo-Yo Ma's Silk Road Ensemble will help introduce the music of Asia. At 3 and 5
title: For Children

title: Spare Times

title: Spare Times

body: ASIDE from the green and white sign with the three-leaf clovers, there isn't much to catch the eye about Mooney's Pub on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, unless you're a frequent passer-by with an apartment nearby and what you had always thought was an uncommon last name. In that case, you wonder idly what these other Mooneys are like, and make a
title: DISPATCHES; Where Everybody Really Did Know His Name

title: Spare Times

body: THERE are some restaurant dishes that I order because they sound better than everything else on the menu, and there are some I order because they sound worse. My reasoning goes like this: If a chef dares to offer something as unappealing as, say, a raw kale salad, chances are it's fantastic. I've played this game at restaurants all over the world,
title: A GOOD APPETITE; If It Sounds Bad, It's Got to Be Good

body: THEY use a pickle jar as a fishbowl, a vintage egg incubator as a stereo stand, and a cobbler's bench as a coffee table. Robert Wilson and Elizabeth Crowell are skilled at the art of repurposing. Their 3,900-square-foot Victorian town house in the Prospect Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn is filled with curiosities that have unexpected pasts.
title: HABITATS | PROSPECT HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; The Ultimate Recyclers

body: Two robbers armed with a handgun held up a storage facility in Prospect Heights and a fast-food restaurant in Clinton Hill yesterday, the police said. title: Brooklyn: Pair Sought In Two Robberies

title: Dance

body: There it is, past the weathered men bent over rows of empty beer bottles headed to a recycler at a nickel apiece. It is parked on the sidewalk and shackled with a thick chain to a rusty old fence. title: PROSPECT HEIGHTS JOURNAL; He Caters to a Brooklyn Kind of Carriage Trade

body: Harvey W. Schultz, New York City's commissioner of environmental protection during the last of Mayor Edward I. Koch's three terms, died in Brooklyn on Sept. 6. He was 66 and lived in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. The cause was a heart attack, his wife, Nanette Rainone, said. Mr. Schultz was chosen to lead the Department of Environmental Protection in
title: Harvey Schultz, 66, Head Of Environmental Agency

body: There is an almost eerie quiet as New York City approaches the September 18 primary elections. No federal, statewide, citywide, City Council, or state legislative posts are at issue, making this the least active primary season in recent memory. This has produced a quirky result: The primary's marquee events are three judicial contests in Brooklyn.
title: THE CITY; A Quiet (and Disquieting) Primary

body: EDWARD FEENEY would rather have been at the beach on a recent Sunday morning. Instead, he was lugging boxes up to the sidewalk from a brownstone basement in Park Slope, Brooklyn, while his wife, Carol Arnold, unpacked them. title: The Retailer Next Door

title: THE HUNT; Companionship, and a Good Deal

Although she was happily sharing a three-bedroom
title: HABITATS | BOERUM HILL, BROOKLYN; Earning an A in Real Estate 101

title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; More Trouble For Foxy Brown

body: FOR CHILDREN 'EAST SIDE STORIES' The teenagers in City Lights Youth Theater have spent the summer acting as amateur archaeologists. But they haven't been excavating some ancient site overseas; they've been digging, at least metaphorically, into the old foundations of Broadway. The results will be presented this afternoon in ''East Side Stories,''
title: Review

body: There were minute-by-minute (and hour-by-hour) accounts of commutes thwarted -- and accomplished, if in triple the usual time. There were comparisons of New York to third-world countries, of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to the Taliban. There were many complaints about rude transit workers, and glimpses of praise for generous bus
title: Anger and Triumph, As Told From Front Line

body: A lone cluster of clouds gathers demurely behind the Con Edison Building as Claire Kuhn and Jessica Watson spread their striped beach towels into a pristine pool of sun that has formed on the roof. Un-self-consciously, they splay their bikini-clad bodies toward the light. On a quest for that ultimate summer badge -- casually sun-tinged skin --
title: SUMMER RITUALS | BLACKTOP BEACH; Dwindling Temples in the Sky for Sun Worshipers

title: Spare Times

body: For a long time, Public School 8 in Brooklyn Heights was so troubled, it served as a sort of benchmark for local parents: If your child was old enough to attend, it was probably time to move out of the neighborhood. Then, starting in 2003, a new principal and a new team of teachers, along with parents and community groups, pursued a spirited
title: Brooklyn Heights; Wanted: A School of Their Own

body: WHEN Janey Lee and Pablo Agüero were struggling freelance Web designers, buying an apartment in Manhattan seemed like a dream, one clouded by credit-card debt, student loans that had to be repaid and the bills for their wedding. But now, five years later, they are about to move into a $445,000 two-bedroom condo in Hamilton Heights, in Upper
title: Every Penny Counts

body: DECADES before Al Gore revved into documentary scold mode and transferred the green state of mind into fashionably green activism with his Academy-Award-winning film, ''An Inconvenient Truth,'' there was Richard M. Cherry. Never heard of him? Mr. Cherry, 64, is one of 15 finalists, and the only local finalist, for the $100,000 Purpose Prize, an
title: PUBLIC LIVES; A Contractor Who Was Green Before Green Was Cool

body: WHEN people ask where I live, I tailor my answer to my audience. If someone with children is asking, I'll answer, ''Park Slope,'' as if I had just won the lottery. If I'm talking to a childless friend who lives somewhere gritty -- say, Bushwick -- I'll duck the question, or mumble that I live near Prospect Park. Lovers and haters of Park Slope are
title: The Park Slope Parent Trap

title: Violin Taken In Subway Is Reunited With Owner

body: Ever since it was proposed, the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn has simultaneously been the borough's biggest, most controversial and least understood real estate development. title: Documents Show Risk In Big Project In Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: Re ''So, Do I Make the Cut?,'' April 29: Neither as renter nor homeowner have I ever come across a dog who: plays his music too loud; blocks my driveway; steals my parking space; lets his trash blow into the street; or leaves the building door ajar. title: Parking, Pollution And the Pricing Zone

title: URBAN TACTICS; The Curtains, The Dog, The Remark

title: A Beautiful Day in the Neighborhood

body: Finally, New York's trees and gardens, so long stuck in a kind of suspended animation, have shaken off winter. When the rain ended abruptly last week, the whole city burst into bloom simultaneously rather than in the usual sequential order. Now's the moment to get outside, walk on the city's side streets under canopies of white Callery pears and
title: Spring in the City

title: The New Kids on the Board

body: New York City wants to strengthen its hand against recalcitrant landlords by giving itself broad new powers to overhaul entire building systems -- like heating, electrical or plumbing -- in long-troubled properties, and to force landlords to pay for the work. A bill to be introduced in the City Council today with the Bloomberg administration's
title: City Seeks Broader Power to Fix Troubled Buildings at Landlords' Expense

title: The Battle for a Mortgage

title: STREET LEVEL/Prospect Heights; Before Bulldozers, The Sound Of Purring

body: A man in jail on Rikers Island has been accused of trying to hire someone to behead Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and to bomb Police Headquarters. The police said the man, David Brown, 47, of Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, was charged yesterday with second-degree criminal solicitation in a plot that was discovered after the police received a
title: Inmate Plotted to Kill Police Leader And Plant a Bomb, Officials Say

body: LIKE most teammates, the chess players who like to gather at Dr. Ronald E. McNair Park in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, share a familial camaraderie. They refer to one another by nicknames like Indiana George and One a Day (the number of times the player won), and offer casual slaps on the back after a particularly good game. They graciously boast
title: URBAN STUDIES / Mastering; The Game of Kings, and a Side of Fries

title: Corrections

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST VILLAGE; Sing Out, Buffy!

body: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Jacqueline Melendez Rivera, a New York City police officer accused of covering up for her husband after the shooting of another officer in Brooklyn, misidentified her neighborhood at one point. She lives in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn -- not Park Slope.
title: Corrections

body: Jacqueline Melendez Rivera is a police officer but not, she says, a traitor to her badge. She is simply a woman, she says, who, concerned about protecting her family, became caught unaware in the aftermath of a crime. Now, her life upended, she stands accused of helping the man she loved cover up an especially damning shooting nine days ago. On
title: A Crisis of Family and Badge

body: Since the new year began, a burst of activity has broken out in Manhattan and several Brooklyn neighborhoods as New Yorkers frenetically hunt for co-ops, condominiums and town houses, sending prices higher despite sluggish sales in many other cities. Preliminary indications from real estate firms showed that this increased activity, with open
title: HOUSING MARKET HEATS UP IN CITY

body: THE proposed Nets arena has been depicted as many things by opponents of the Atlantic Yards project, but a gigantic, shining toilet bowl is the most eye-catching critique to date. The artwork is one of more than 50 works that appeared last fall in an exhibition, ''Footprints: Portrait of a Brooklyn Neighborhood,'' at Grand Space, a community center
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; An Exhibition Notable For What's Not There

title: Corrections

body: The police officer charged with covering up for her husband after the shooting of another officer in Brooklyn has faced four allegations of wrongdoing during her 13-year career, all of which were found to be unsubstantiated, police officials said yesterday. title: Police Officer Faces Scrutiny After Shooting of Colleague

author: Johanna Baldwin is a writer and producer who is currently working on a collection of short stories.
body: I'D met the happily married man several times, always at one of the parties Doug gave in his loft in TriBeCa, but we never got to know each other very well. He was alarmingly kind, and of course married, but for some reason, his happily married wife and I didn't remember each other. Could be because Doug's loft seems to be the size of a football
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; A Guest Encounters Happiness, And a Bit Of Babyland
